Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 09:17AM Skyrat wrote: Maybe you could be a bit sneaky about it - maybe tell her that you had BC and just feel a need to talk about it.  And in the course of conversation, mention that if she needs anything, you can help.  Maybe if she knows that someone else has been there, she will look to you for information and assistance.  It's a touchy situation since the information came third hand, but if you open the door, maybe she will be forthcoming.  Hugs for being such a caring person.
Posts.Title: Do I get involved or not? Poppy Poppy

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 03:35AM Skyrat wrote: Jacqdan - a year ago, 12 Apr, I was in about the same situation.  It was my mother's birthday and my husband's birthday that I had the lumpectomy and lymph node removal with an immediate diagnosis.  My parents were celebrating my mother's birthday, so I waited until they got home.  Telling my family was the hardest part of all this. Right now, you have a lot to take in.  A lot of anxiety as well.  But it does pass.  The oncologists are really good at making sure you have the medications to help you deal with anxiety, nausea, sleeping issues, depression, etc.  Stay on top of things during your treatment. I take it that your doctor has biopsied the lump?  My experience was that nobody could say for sure that I had cancer without the biopsy - they could just tell me that it didn't feel good or look good.  With the biopsy came the staging. One thing that I found through all this, is that the cancer becomes secondary as you deal with the treatment.  Do keep us informed.  So sorry you had to join us!
Posts.Title: im scared jacqdan sueper13

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 10:34AM Skyrat wrote: I got my handicap hanger from my onc.  Explain to your doc that without the hanger, grocery shopping is almost impossible.  The doc can fill out the paperwork, or his receptionist can, and once he's signed it, you just go to the license bureau with it and get your hangers immediately.  We have two vehicles, so I got two hangers.
Posts.Title: lymphadema as disability soccermom kira

Posts.Content: Skyrat wrote: My last chemo was Nov 6 2007.  Just in the past 3 weeks I have begun to have some weird things happening.  Just as I'm on the verge of sleep or right after I fall to sleep, my leg muscles will start clenching and unclenching.  It's not painful, but if I don't do something about it, my left arm begins to spasm.  Usually one Ativan at night will prevent this from happening, but once in a while I have to get up for a second.  Has anyone else had these type of symptoms?  The oncologist seems to think it is restless leg syndrome, but my symptoms don't match.  There is no pain, I don't feel the need to move my legs - but the clenching of the muscles feels like the taste you get when you bite down on foil paper.  My chemo was 15 weekly Adriamycin and daily Cytoxin, followed by 11 weekly treatments of Taxol.  I had a double mastectomy on Dec 26.  Any ideas?  Thanks! 5-1-08, Stage IV mets to the spine, 19/21 nodes metastatic adenode carcinoma, abundant vascular involvement; skyratgina.vox.com/ Dx 4/12/2007, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 19/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Symptoms after Chemo Skyrat Skyrat

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 04:21PM Skyrat wrote: *HUGS* to you Dragonfly.  I was just diagnosed with mets to the spine, ribs and possibly the sternum.  Welcome to Stage IV.  I was somewhat prepared for it though with my first diagnosis.  Know that there are many sisters out here who feel your fear and your concern.
Posts.Title: FRom A 11 to Iv in 30 seconds Dragonfly-4 Gitane

Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 09:53AM Skyrat wrote: abrede - Your experience sounds a lot like mine.  I had found a lump on the side of my breast.  Made an appointment with my PCP for a pap smear and breast exam.  She felt the lump, said it didn't feel good, but they couldn't be 100% sure it was cancer without a biopsy.  She gave me literature on breast cancer and set up a diagnostic mammo and ultrasound.  The doc reading them came in and told me he couldn't be 100% sure it was cancer without a biopsy, but it didn't look good.  PCP made an appointment with a surgeon - who offered a lumpectomy with SNB or mastectomy.  I opted for the lumpectomy.  Long story longer - they had a pathologist standing by with the lumpectomy, so when I recovered from the anesthesia I had my diagnosis.  Prayers are with you that all your news be good.  Keep us posted!
Posts.Title: It's all happening so fast.. abrede Looneymom

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 03:46PM Skyrat wrote: I have quit trying to wear rings at all.  One thing after having my lymph nodes removed is that I am afraid of lymphedema just popping up and having to have the rings cut off.  Also, my fingers swell - not sure if it's because of the node removal or the arthritic side effects of Aromasin.
Posts.Title: Trouble wearing ring on SNB side? mom2two KatherineA

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 11:03PM Skyrat wrote: Mom2two - The thing that concerns me about the possibility of a LE flare up with rings on is the possibility of not being able to get to a hospital in time and having to lose a finger.  So just play it safe instead of sorry.  Not to mention that my knuckles are enlarged from the arthritis SE of the Aromasin.
Posts.Title: Trouble wearing ring on SNB side? mom2two KatherineA

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2007 12:15PM Skyrat wrote: Roxy - what a gloom and doom doctor you have!  I am a Locally Advanced Stage IIIC with adenode carcinoma in 19/21 lymph nodes and extensive vascular invasion.  If I look at the stats, I have a 20% of 5 year survival.  My tumor was a Grade 3, very aggressive.  I am so excited to have just completed 7 months of weekly chemo...(15 weeks of daily Cytoxin with the Adriamycin).  I get nothing but positive from my doctor, surgeon and oncologist.  Statistics are just numbers - I will survive and be cancer free!  So will you.
Posts.Title: kemo today roxy42 Skyrat

Posts.Content: May 1, 2008 12:11AM - edited May 1, 2008 12:12AM by Skyrat Sugar, I do feel for you.  I completed rads 3 Apr.  Was told at the last treatment that I would continue to cook for 2 1/2 weeks.  About the last 2 treatments I was beginning to have painful burns.  By a week after the last treatment, I was in tears.  The creams burned when I put them on, nothing relieved the pain.  I visited the radiation onc, told him the pain I was having and that the creams burnt too bad to use.  Told him that I didn't need any watered down pain meds like Vicodin and Percocet.  He prescribed oxycontin, which really did relieve the pain!  I took it once in the morning and once at night when I went to bed for about 4 days, and by that time, the burns were healing and Ibuprofen would take care of the discomfort.
Posts.Title: radiation therapy....after sugarsunnyjugs Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 11:29AM Skyrat wrote: I was 50 at diagnosis.  I had been experiencing menopause since about 40 - night sweats, insomnia, fatigue.  I would come home from work and want to do nothing but sleep.  I put that down to the stress at work.  Now I wonder.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Is it true there are no symptoms other than breast changes? PeaceChild kiki

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 08:50PM Skyrat wrote: I've had three infusions of Abraxane so far - two with Avastin.  I get my infusions every week, with every other week including the Avastin.  I have to say that out of 6 different chemo cocktails, this has been the easiest.  I haven't noticed any side effects.  I take 300 mg of B6 a day and gargle with warm salt and baking soda water.  No mouth sores.  I have some hair loss - but it's been an easy chemo so far.  Good luck with your treatments!
Posts.Title: Abraxane coming up AliceJean AliceJean

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 09:58PM Skyrat wrote: I wouldn't know how to go about finding a surgeon or any body for that matter.  I have been fortunate in that all the doctors I've had to see have been referrals.  After discovering a lump in my left breast, I made an appointment for a pap smear and breast exam.  My doctor felt the lump, said "it doesn't feel good" and gave me literature on breast cancer and an appointment for a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound.  The guy that read the films came in after the ultrasound and said "it doesn't look good" and set me up for a surgery consult.  The only biopsy choices I was offered was a lumpectomy or mastectomy.  Since nobody would go out on a limb and say Yes, we think it's cancer, I chose a lumpectomy.  Couldn't get clear margins, so had a reincission - still no clear margin.  Diagnosis:  Locally Advanced Stage IIIC with metastatic adenocarcinoma and abundant vascular invasion.  Next thing I know, I am meeting my oncologist.  So much for 2007.  LOL  I slept through it.
Posts.Title: How were you told basil16883 AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2007 03:09PM Skyrat wrote: So sorry to hear that you were diagnosed. I am a Stage IIIC Locally Advanced BC Patient right now. I was not offered a needle biopsy - my choices were lumpectomy or mastectomy, at which time they would biopsy the tumor. I opted for the lumpectomy; but wishing I had gone ahead with the mastectomy. I am on 6 months of weekly treatments of Adriamycin, daily doses of Cytoxin and Neuprogen. I am told that after the 6 months of chemo, I will have 3 months of radiation, then a mastectomy (provided the cancer doesn't show up anywhere else). You are in my thoughts and prayers - and attitude is everything. Positive attitude makes everything just a little easier to handle.
Posts.Title: yup, it's cancer Methusala figsgirls

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 06:20AM Skyrat wrote: TCL - I spent maybe a total of 5 hours filling out the two applications online.  Took my documents (driver's license, birth certificate, W2, etc) to the local office so they could make their copies.  About 4 weeks later my first check was deposited retro back to Oct when my short term disability ended.  My medical team must have been on top of things to get the copies of my medical records to SS.
Posts.Title: SSDI with stage 4 cancer tclawmen Hrlady53

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2008 06:45AM - edited Jun 13, 2008 06:46AM by Skyrat I haven't posted in a while because I certainly don't want to scare people who are new to the diagnosis - but I do want to say, dolphinsac, I followed the whole procedure that was recommended.  I am 51 now, was 50 when first diagnosed.  I had not seen a doctor in years because of a phobia of doctors.  I went through the lumpectomy and lymph node removal, a reincission, 26 weeks of chemo, a bilateral mastectomy and 33 rads.  In spite of this, the cancer spread.  In my mind, this was meant to be - I had done EVERYTHING I could to avoid being a Stage IV.  If you choose to skip a step, how would you feel if the cancer spread?  If one surgeon won't put you out for the procedure, find one that will...but don't skip the surgery.
Posts.Title: Unable to commit to surgery dolphinsac sbmolee

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 08:00AM Skyrat wrote: Bridget - I would be surprised if your onc did not want a PET Scan or MRI after all your treatment is finished since you did have positive nodes.  I had my first PET Scan on 1 May 2007...went through chemo, surgery and rads, then had my 2nd PET Scan on 1 May 2008.  During treatment, the only time I received scans was when I complained about some symptom that concerned the onc - then he would order a CT Scan.  I haven't heard of or been offered a test of the bone marrow, but that may be coming.

Posts.Title: IDC diagnosis this week Lisa1965 Lisa1965

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 10:02AM Skyrat wrote: Bridget - I think I would have to insist on scans after treatment.  I have bone mets - didn't have any overt symptoms, and what I did have, I thought was due to the lasting effects of chemo and radiation.  While mets was not something I wanted, I am glad that they were discovered before I really began having pain.  It is surprising though how many docs don't do scans.  I would much rather have a false positive than to have something going on and not know about it.  Good luck cancer sister, prayers are with you.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 11:58AM Skyrat wrote: I don't consider myself sick.  As I tell people who make comments about my being sick - I am not sick.  I have no cold, flu, or other illness - I'm fine, other than I'm cancerous.
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 10:53AM Skyrat wrote: CanuckinTX:  I like your handle - I'm originally from TX, living in WA just a stone's throw from the Canadian border.  Anyway, it would be highly irritating to have people react with 'you have the best kind of cancer' or otherwise minimalize it.  Regardless, it has changed your life - you have been touched by the big "C", and that will always be with you.  And to anybody who would say something like that, I would have to ask them if they really believe that there is a 'best kind of cancer'.  When I was first diagnosed, still reeling from the news and the first couple of ops to try to get clean margins, I applied for my short-term disability.  The first thing the guy says to me when I tell him why was:  Lots of people have breast cancer, and they still work.  I wish now I had been on top of things and gotten that jerk's name.  Take care and may your news always be positive!
Posts.Title: The "BEST" Kind of Breast Cancer!!! canuckintx Skyrat

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 05:27PM Skyrat wrote: Denial?????  Hah!!!!  I only wish I could retreat into denial - but that's never been an option since my DX and restaging.  A terminal disease - yes.  Sick?  No.  I did not feel well going through treatments, and at times I did get sick.  Being sick would indicate that there is a cure in the near future.  But then, it's variety that makes the world go round, and the definition of sick is relative.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 12:26AM Skyrat wrote: For what it is worth, here is my opinion.  I would want to know.  PET Scan, MRI, CT Scan, Bone Scan...scan crazy.  Had my mets showed up in the beginning, my treatment would have been quite a bit different.  When metastisis hasn't been diagnosed, the attitude is to treat to cure.  Once metastisis is diagnosed, the treatment is geared more for trying to get a remission - not as aggressive as trying to get a cure.  However, the choice is always up to you.  I pushed my double mastectomy through before I had been diagnosed with mets.  Once that diagnosis came in, they would not have done the surgery since the cancer was already metastisized.

LOL Don't know whether to be relieved or worried. But - survival rates are just numbers. Hang in there and fight hard. A positive attitude may be hard to maintain at this point, but remember - as long as there is life, there is hope. I don't know what your faith may be, but in my fight, I let God carry me. You will be in my prayers.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 06:23AM Skyrat wrote: Libby - when I had my initial surgery consult for biopsy, we discussed the lumpectomy vs mastectomy.  Since they could not be 100% sure it was cancer without the biopsy, I elected the lumpectomy.  The survival and recurrence stats were about the same.  Due to the extent of my cancer, I will now need a mastectomy after my chemo is finished and before my rads start - at least that is if the cancer is not found elsewhere.

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy & axillary dissection ?? loriann frogger

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 04:16AM Skyrat wrote: Roseanne - I have a number of bone lesions, they are cancerous blastio lesions that show up on a PET/CT Scan, MRI and CT Scan, but not a bone scan.  Mazy - I am also on Aromasin and Zometa and am very pleased that there has been no advance of the cancer and that all but two of the lesions are inactive now, and the ones that are active are not doing anything.
Posts.Title: solitary bone lesion roseanne LuAnnH

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 10:33AM - edited May 14, 2009 10:33AM by Skyrat Jennifer - I first filled out a form on the internet, which I was supposed to get a phone call for an interview.  That never came, so the day after the interview was scheduled, I went in to the office.  In hindsight, I would do that first just for the contact.  I explained to the lady that I was Stage IV BC.  She promised to put a rush on my request and gave me the paperwork to fill out, told me I could either do it that way or by internet.  I filled out the paperwork on the internet (took about 2-3 hours), then the following day, took the documentation they were going to need (birth certificate, SS card) so they could make the copies.  Three weeks after my application, I had my first check back dated to the first day after my short term disability had ended.  Since I am not of age, I had to wait 24 months to qualify for Medicare, which will happen in Oct of this year. They were compassionate and quick.  They did request my medical records, but told me it was not up to the doctor but their panel as to whether I was disabled or not - and what I put in the app would have more weight than a note from the doc.  Fortunately, I'd had my onc fill out the FMLA form stating that I was not able to work at that time.  That has not been rescinded and will not be. Apparently the medical personnel were quick to respond to the request for records, and it all went quite smoothly and quickly.
Posts.Title: Social Security/Perm Disability - How do you go about it? JeninMichigan Brenda_R

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2009 10:08AM Skyrat wrote: Chris - when I was first diagnosed with bone mets May 2008, I was put on the Zometa and Aromasin treatment.  It put the bone mets in remission for about 8 months.  I have since been doing the CMF treatment.  I have 3 months more of 14-day cycles of Cytoxan, then I will be done with this round of chemo and see what comes after that.  My onc took me off the Aromasin since it was not doing anything to keep the ER/PR+ cancer cells from setting up parties elsewhere in my body.  I am still on monthly infusions of Zometa though.
Posts.Title: Please help my friend with bone mets GoodMommy GoodMommy

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 07:17PM Skyrat wrote: I had 21 nodes removed and flew from WA to MO and back..no problems.  BUT  I did wear a compression sleeve.  Since you don't have time to get one fitted, I would check with a pharmacy and get one to wear until you can get a fitted sleeve.  Not sure how flying without a sleeve would do.
Posts.Title: I am flying this week,uh oh lymphedema? skigrl kira

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 08:12AM Skyrat wrote: Jeannette - I had my bilateral, no reconstruction, 26 Dec.  I didn't have any pain for the longest time.  Then I developed a seroma which decided to drain on its own.  Went in, and the surgeon helped continue the draining.  I now have more buildup of fluid (seroma), and do have a bit of pain.  I would follow up with the surgeon to see if this might be what you are experiencing.  I have also, as of today, completed 26 of 33 rad treatments.  The scar on the left side has held up real well under the radiation.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy - PAIN jeanette51 dlm425

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 08:40PM Skyrat wrote: Goldie - it's way too early for you to give up.  I am a locally advanced stage IIIC, with 19 of 21 nodes positive for metastatic adenode carcinoma (the surgeon said he didn't need a biopsy once he opened me up - the nodes were ruptured and fused together visually) and abundant vascular invasion.  I had 15 weekly treatments of Adriamycin and daily Cytoxin; and 11 weekly Taxol treatments.  So far, so good!  They have not found cancer anywhere else.  The good news is - I am hormone positive, so will be treated with a hormone blocker for 5 years.  I know there's something else they treat HER2+, but don't know what that is.  Until you are on your deathbed, there is always hope.
Posts.Title: I'm startng to feel so hopeless! Please help me out! Goldie dhettish

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2007 06:31PM Skyrat wrote: Woo Hoo Linda Lou! Congratulations! And your good news couldn't have come at a better time.
Posts.Title: Sharing Good News in Hopes of Encouraging Others! LindaLou53 LauraGTO

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 02:28AM Skyrat wrote: Kenzie - I am not sure about the employment law.  I know in the state of WA, unless you carry long term disability, the employer is not required to provide anything but an offer of COBRA when you leave your job for any reason.  Under the Disabled Persons Act, they are only required to provide reasonable access and comfort for disabled employees.  When I was moved up to Stage IV, I resigned from the job and applied for SSDI.  No lawyer was needed, and they expedited my claim.  Within a month of applying, I had my first check dated back to the month my shortterm disability ended.  One thing to be aware of is if you are carrying life insurance through your employer, you should be able to keep it - premium free.  This is something you have to apply for.  I can work and make up to $600 a month and not affect my SSDI.  If you can document discrimination, go for it.  WA is a state where they can let you go or fire you whether there is a reason or not.  I have one more year to wait for Medicare - in the meantime, my husband is carrying the health insurance.
Posts.Title: Help: Thinking about disability again kenzie57 kenzie57

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 06:49PM Skyrat wrote: Kim - I had a bilateral 26 Dec 08.  I was in the hospital 4 days and then released with no drains.  YaY!  But - I had no problems doing my hair, getting dressed as long as I didn't have to put my hands over my head.  I was able to do everything for myself except get things from higher shelves.  Getting back to presurgery condition physically took a while longer - but from day one, the surgeon had me doing the spider up the wall walk with both arms.  I would stop when I felt it, so by the time I got home, I did have quite a bit of mobility.  I didn't not have a lot of pain, and what pain I did have was relieved with Vicodin.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: March, bilateral masectomy rascal_gal Skyrat

Posts.Content: Skyrat wrote: From the first day of my diagnosis, I have been accepting - by God's grace I have accepted my diagnosis, treatment, restaging, remission, and the new mets party going on with a whole new round of chemo.  I started my CMF a week ago today, 21 Apr 09.  With the Prednisone, Dexamethasone and Benadryl premed, the MF infusions, and the daily Cytoxin, I just keep on going and going and going.  Smiling my way through, accepting that which I cannot change, determined to go as far as I can.  Well, not sure what's happened.  Friday was my first pain free day since 12 Apr 2007.  Yesterday, I even got out and gardened a bit - today, I feel NORMAL pains of doing work that I am no longer accustomed to.  But yesterday was something else.  I asked my onc and the onc nurses - could I be having a psychotic break?  Is it side effects of chemo?  What is going on?  I felt rage...a very dangerous rage and one that scared me because I was going to act on that rage.  I put myself in the bedroom and shut the door - warned my husband that if he wanted to live, to leave me alone.  Kept myself from the new puppy, because I just wanted to smash it over and over against the house.  These were not just imaginings or thinking of things to relieve the rage...it was something I so easily was beginning to act upon.  I removed myself, which was a good thing.  The onc and the nurses feel it could very well be a psychotic break and that I was fortunate enough to recognize symptoms and stop the actions.  It could also be a side effect of the chemo.  It could also be, that for the first time since this all started, I realized THIS was the rest of my life. What is 'THIS'?  Doctor visits.  Chemo.  Remission.  Doctor visits.  Chemo.  Remission.  For how long?  How long do I want to keep treatments going?  Every time the mets pop up again?  Actually, right now, I do have an answer to that question - for as long as I don't have the pain!  And if chemo with mets stops the pain, I suppose that it will be the cycle til it just don't work anymore or I am cured.  LOL Anyway - I do have a door open if I feel the need to talk to a counselor.  But, it is going to be interesting to see - if this is a side effect of the chemo, along about next Monday I will be on the phone to the oncology clinic giving them the symptoms I am feeling.  If it's not the chemo, then we will work from there - maybe up my antidepressant or antianxiety. Why am I writing such a lengthy book on a site where so many people are too busy to really want to be bothered reading - well, I am wondering if anyone else on CMF has had these feelings.  I'm not talking about the feelings of 'wanting' to do something violent - I'm talking about the feeling where the things you love, you pets, family, become the object of your rage and there is a very REAL probability of hurt being put on them.  I am hoping like he** I am not the only one! 5-1-08, Stage IV mets to the spine, 19/21 nodes metastatic adenode carcinoma, abundant vascular involvement; skyratgina.vox.com/ Dx 4/12/2007, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 19/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Sunday Truth, CMF, and Forever Skyrat Skyrat

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 02:22PM Skyrat wrote: Ladies - I do so appreciate your comments and input.  After feeling normal now today and yesterday, I am believing that it was really roid rage.  How scary to be so out of control!  Barbe - I am a fan of Zoloft myself - thinking about asking to up the dosage after Monday's scare. Lisa - I am so glad you have not had to experience these feelings.  I was on Prednisone and Dexamethasone for my first 26 weeks of chemo and NEVER experienced such a loss of control!  That's why I think it had to be a reaction with this new chemo and the Prednisone.  Ugh. M - I had fortunately read about 'psychotic breaks' for people who had committed murder on Prednisone.  Having been a self-treater for 50 years, I am so thankful that I am still in tune enough with my body to have caught myself before my poor little dog was a bloody smear on the side of the house. Bethie - I keep thinking about counseling but then ask myself why.  There are no answers to my questions.  LOL  But anymore of Monday's loss of control, I will be looking all over for the reason. Fitztwins - Hugs to you lady.  I have been reading this board since my diagnosis and you have been a constant inspiration to me. Flash - I have given my husband instructions just in case I don't recognize the symptoms one day. He is to hogtie me, throw me in the car and take me to the ER - dump me on them and say "roid rage" and then get out of sight.  What a trip! I want you all to know that you are in my thoughts and prayers and I do read these boards daily.  You all are inspirations and I do hope that those newly diagnosed, regardless of stage, will read this thread.  Stage IV ladies are amazing - and you are a good portion of my strength.
Posts.Title: Sunday Truth, CMF, and Forever Skyrat Skyrat

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 09:06AM Skyrat wrote: Kim - the second surgery was actually worse than the first time around.  But - I had full range of motion and no pain by the time the chemo started 3 weeks later.  They were going to wait 4 weeks, but I had healed so well.
Posts.Title: Going back for re-excision next week Kim64 Jo-Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 04:49PM Skyrat wrote: You're right kimbly - you will get through this.  I can't speak for reconstruction, but my bilateral mastectomy was a breeze.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Next is surgery kimbly smilee

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 06:41AM Skyrat wrote: I see a general onc who specializes in breast cancer.  He is in close contact with the university and stays up on all the latest treatments for all types of cancer.  I feel like I have the best care and totally trust that he does everything possible to keep my cancer in check.
Posts.Title: Breast Onc or General Onc? Kasey pinkpig

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 11:06AM Skyrat wrote: Kim - on Apr 12, 2007 I had a lumpectomy.  On Apr 17, 2007 I had a reincission to try to get clear margins.  I don't think I could have handled a longer wait, because I already had a 4-week wait between surgery and starting chemo.  All went well with the surgeries so close together.
Posts.Title: Going back for re-excision next week Kim64 Jo-Anne

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 04:48AM Skyrat wrote: I cannot say enough good things about the AFLAC cancer policy.  When I was first diagnosed with cancer in Apr 2007, I turned in a claim.  The first check I got was before any treatments and it was enough to allow me to pay off our credit cards and a few other bills.  They paid so much per infusion of chemo, the oral chemo pills and the neupogen shots.  When I had my bilateral mastectomy, they paid a certain amount for the days I was in the hospital and if I'm not mistaken, also a part of the surgical fee.  They paid a certain amount for each radiation treatment.  They are also paying a portion of each Zometa infusion I have.  It is nice that their rates are not based on whether you have other insurance - AFLAC has a certain amount that they pay for each claim.  I also enjoy that the checks come to me for me to do what needs to be done with them.  I have never had a problem and highly recommend AFLAC for anybody with access to it and who hasn't yet been diagnosed with cancer or has been cancer free for 5 years.  I am also so very thankful that as long as I maintain premium payment, I and my husband are covered even though I no longer have the job.  It has been thanks to AFLAC that we have been able to survive financially with the claims coverage.
Posts.Title: Aflac Cancer Policy prnciss74 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 04:52AM Skyrat wrote: Oh yeah - as I said, I can't say enough good things about AFLAC.  They are quick to fill the claims as well.  I can fax in a claim and have a check the following week.  I am very impressed with them.
Posts.Title: Aflac Cancer Policy prnciss74 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2007 05:31PM Skyrat wrote: I also had a lumpectomy with a reincission to try to clear margins.  They used the same first incission.  They removed lymph nodes the first time around, and alot more tissue the second time.  The second surgery was by far the most painful.
Posts.Title: 2nd surgery after lumpectomy jaxmos jeanettee

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 11:12AM Skyrat wrote: Dragonfly - your onc and cancer doctor actually gave you a life span????  Hmmmm... the one thing both my surgeon and onc told me was that if any doctor should tell me how long I have left to live, I should run as fast as I can to a different doctor.  No wonder you felt deflated!  Bone cancer is not necessarily a death sentence and can be controlled for years.
Posts.Title: Bone mets riverinerabbit riverinerabbit

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 04:42PM Skyrat wrote: Mom07 - first, let me say I am a smoker.  I have not quit yet, though I do intend to do so when I have my bilateral mastectomy wo reconstruction on Dec 26.  I had no history of breast cancer in my family - I did the geneology thing with death certificates and obits back to the 1700's.  When diagnosed, I decided to do some research and found that breast cancer is one of the very few cancers that has no correlation to smoking.  You did not give yourself breast cancer by lighting up the good old cancer sticks.  I would not have been surprised to be diagnosed with lung cancer, heart disease or diabetes...the lung cancer because I smoke...the other two because they are rampant in my family.  So, sooner or later you may decide to quit - I could not have during the treatment time.  I was diagnosed Apr 12, 2007 with locally advanced Stage IIIC, 19/21 lymph nodes positive for matastatic adenocarcinoma and abundant vascular invasion.  I have completed 15 weeks of AC, and 12 weeks of Taxol.  Now I think I am ready to quit with surgery, then will do the 3 months of radiation.  Hang in there - you did not give yourself breast cancer by smoking.
Posts.Title: smoking mom07 Jenn51

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 07:16PM Skyrat wrote:
Posts.Title: smoking mom07 Jenn51

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 01:31PM Skyrat wrote: Estepp - the abundant vascular invasion and metastatic adenocarcinoma of the lymph nodes was in my original lumpectomy biopsy.  I think that they find this in a lumpectomy biopsy - unless they remove tissue other than the cancer tumor, I'm not sure how they would find it.
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 11:29PM Skyrat wrote: Dragonfly - I feel your pain.  I had 33 rad treatments.  I did real well - took my vitamin E cream with me and put it on immediately after treatment, then several times that day, along with 100% Aloe Gel.  The last 2 treatments, I began to burn some.  The last treatment they told me I would continue to cook for 2 1/2 weeks.  Sure enough, 1 week after treatment ended, I had to go in and see the rad onc and cry on his shoulder because of the pain.  He gave me a scrip for oxycontin - that was a lifesaver!  After about 4 days with the help of oxycontin, the burns began to heal and I was able to control the pain with Ibuprofin or Acetominophen.  Good luck in your treatments!
Posts.Title: I want to quit Dragonfly92127 twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 07:52PM Skyrat wrote: Otter - I was also diagnosed with IDC but did have positive nodes.  I opted for the lumpectomy.  They didn't get clear margins, so had to have it redone.  Still no clear margins, so now I had to have a mastectomy and still have rads.  If they don't get clear margins in the breast tissue with a lumpectomy, you may wind up having to have a mastectomy and radiation anyway.  Weigh your options and discuss til it's dead with your onc and surgeon.
Posts.Title: Feeling pressured to have lumpectomy instead of mastectomy otter irishdreama

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 04:24PM Skyrat wrote: Mikey - if you do a search for lupus and breast cancer, there's quite a few sites that address these issues together
Posts.Title: Lupus sufferer just diagnosed... Mikey2o7 Janet23

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 08:09AM Skyrat wrote: I have to laugh everytime someone tells me how good I look.  I remember when I was first diagnosed, I could see myself looking like a holocaust victim by the end of treatment.  It still amazes me that I didn't lose any weight.  Darn.  It was explained to me when my treatment plan was first laid out.  They begin treating to get rid of the cancer.  If it metastisizes, they can't 'get rid of it' at that point, but will do everything they can to put it in remission or prolong our quality of life.  I managed to have about an 8-month remission, before the mets began a serious party this time around.
Posts.Title: But you look so great, you don't even look sick virginiamom Heidi_Ho

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 12:05PM Skyrat wrote: Laura - I originally opted for a lumpectomy - after all, losing the breast is permanent.  The lumpectomy did not give clear margins so I had a reincission.  Still no clear margins, so my onc told me that because of the amount of vascular invasion and the lack of clear margins, I would need a mastectomy after chemo.  I gave things a lot of thought - it was made clear to me from the beginning that the cancer in the breast was extensive and that the probability of it metastisizing was very good.  However, they had the treatments and in a perfect world, chemo would kill the cancer cells...so, I decided if I have to have one removed, I would go for a bilateral with no reconstruction.  It is a decision I do not regret, as once you move to Stage IV as I have, they treat cancer differently and would not necessarily consider another mastectomy as an option.  When they biopsied the breast tissue in the left breast - after chemo - there were still cancer cells in the tissue.  So, for me, I made the best choice.
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 06:01AM Skyrat wrote: I wish you the best of luck in your care and treatment.  You will find AFLAC to be a blessing and one thing that eases the financial burden to a degree.  It does suck that a person has to worry about insurance and stuff on top of getting hit upside the head with a cancer diagnosis.  Do hope the spots turn out to be nothing - there were five spots in my lungs and two lymph nodes (one in the groin and one in the neck) that showed up as hot spots and turned out to be nothing other than leftover granulomas from pneumonia in the lungs.  Hugs and prayers!
Posts.Title: Aflac Cancer Policy prnciss74 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 05:01PM Skyrat wrote: You generally lose range of motion by not using the muscles while you're healing.  My surgeon told me as soon as I went home (with the lumpectomy and node removal; then after going home on the 4th day after a bilateral) to start doing the spider up the wall.  In the beginning he wanted me to do it til I felt it, then quit.  It was amazing at how quickly I gained the range of motion back on both sides.  good luck!
Posts.Title: range of motion after surgery rayhope karen1956

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 03:13PM Skyrat wrote: If that's pain control in Canada - thank goodness I'm not there!  My rad onc prescribed oxycontin for my pain.  I still have to take oxycontin and vicodin for the side effect pain of Aromasin.
Posts.Title: Pain and how this was handled, NOT happy QueenK tigerlili001

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 02:54PM Skyrat wrote: It is normal to feel the way you are feeling.  I know when I was first diagnosed, I lived and died with the words 'You have cancer'.  After 7 months of weekly and daily chemo, a bilateral mastectomy and 33 rad treatments, I was diagnosed with mets to the bones in May of this year.  This month I had a bone scan which shows no cancer...so, for the time being I am flirting with NED and will consider myself cancer free until otherwise.  I will not waste a moment of my life worrying about it.  Prayers and thoughts are with you.
Posts.Title: 4 posive nodes kiddy Diana4Rita

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 09:01AM Skyrat wrote: Vivian - I had a double mastectomy in Dec 2007.  I opted for no reconstruction and am very happy with my choice.  I learned a long time ago that if a man loves me for my boobs, he's in a world of hurt as I age - it was getting hard to find them!  I love the freedom (no-I have yet to get a prosthesis) of no bra (hadn't been able to go braless since 4th grade!), nothing slapping my knees as I walk around the house, and when I lay on my back, I can actually have my arms by my side without the boobs getting in the way.  I also decided that I did not want anything to stand in the way of being able to detect another lump.  Not to mention - I no longer have mammograms (I certainly didn't like my first and only one!).  However, to reconstruct or not, is certainly a very personal decision.  I, personally, am very happy.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2007 07:48AM Skyrat wrote: Linda - when I was on AC, I had to give myself 2 shots of Neupogen a day for 6 days each week for 15 weeks.  I was told when it was prescribed, to give the shots in my abdomen or the back side of my arms.  I was also told after my lumpectomy with lymph node removal, that nothing was to be given on the left side.  So, I used the right side of my abdomen.  And, since being diagnosed with cancer, I am such a pain wimp, I would gently poke myself with the needle until I found a spot that I didn't feel the needle.  It was amazing to me how much of the abdomen has no feeling.  Merry Christmas, and the best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Neupogen Shots smithlme Binney4

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 02:07AM Skyrat wrote: Oh yes - just wanted to add that my outlook is that I am not dieing of cancer, I am living in spite of it.  And I will not spend one minute worrying about dieing - that is a waste of my time living.
Posts.Title: 4 posive nodes kiddy Diana4Rita

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 02:06AM Skyrat wrote: Kiddy - I have probably an odd view of the diagnosis.  When the surgeon told me, I asked him what he planned to do about it...and the ball started rolling.  I am not afraid of dieing - sooner or later I will die.  More what bothers me and gives me the most anxiety is dieing a cancer death.  IF I would die without being in a lot of pain and still be able to take care of myself up to the second, then I would be ok.  However, I don't think cancer is going to get me.  I have a lot of faith and a lot of people praying for me.  It boiled down to dealing with the treatments and the side effects...at times I completely forgot about the cancer.  In fact, I have not had any cancer pain.  LOL  I maintain a realistic view of having cancer and am well aware of the extent of my cancer.  I think the biggest part of dealing with cancer is being a realist with faith.
Posts.Title: 4 posive nodes kiddy Diana4Rita

Posts.Content: Skyrat wrote: Today I had an MRI and a bone scan.  On 1 May, I was diagnosed with bone mets to two ribs, 4 T-vertebrae, one L-vertebrae, the pelvis, and a femur.  This was by PET Scan, and was confirmed with a CT Scan last month.  Today I am told my bone scan was clear.  So, if I have mets to the bones, why would they not show up on the bone scan? 5-1-08, Stage IV mets to the spine, 19/21 nodes metastatic adenode carcinoma, abundant vascular involvement; skyratgina.vox.com/ Dx 4/12/2007, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 19/21 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Confused about scan results Skyrat LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 02:43PM Skyrat wrote: Roberta - so sorry to see you join us.  Does it get easier to go to the doctor?  Hmmmm...on one hand, yes - on the other no.  The easier part is that the oncologist should listen to you and give you what is needed to relieve anxiety, pain and depression.  On the other side, I can say after almost a year of treatment, I still have to drag myself to the appointments. Your path report looks promising.  I had abundant vascular invasion - so a double mastectomy was performed after almost 7 months of chemo.  I had 19 out of 21 lymph nodes determined to be metastatic adenode carcinoma.  On the 29th I will have another PET Scan and am keeping my fingers crossed that the lymph nodes did their job and kept the cancer cells from going any farther. Prayers are with you throughout your treatment!
Posts.Title: PATHOLOGY REPORT roberta37 crazydaisy
